trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of saffron supplementation on vision in patients with early dry age-related macular degeneration
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Patients with atrophic age-related macular degeneration and the effect of saffron supplementation compared with placebo in improving visual and electrophysiological outcomes

interventions.interventions: Oral Saffron supplementation with 20 mg daily for a 3 month period with possible time period extension based on results. There is no wash out period.
interventions.comparator: Placebo treatment with a gelatin capsule daily

primaryOutcome.outcome: Visual Function as assessed by ETDRS visual acuity
primaryOutcome.timepoint: visual acuity will be assessed monthly for 6 months using a standardised ETDRS (early treatment of diabetic retinopathy study) visual acuity chart

primaryOutcome.outcome: Visual Function as assessed by multifocal electroretinogram findings
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Multifocal electroretinography will be performed at baseline, 3 and 6 month data points

primaryOutcome.outcome: Visual Function as assessed by flicker frequency microperimetry
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Perimetry performed at baseline, 3 and 6 month data points

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life as assessed by NEI-VFQ 25
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: NEI-VFQ 25 performed at baseline, 3 and 6 month data points

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Clinical diagnosis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) as determined by a qualified retinal specialist Ability to participate in electroretinographic examination
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Significant ocular media opacities Other retinal disease (i.e. diabetes, glaucoma, retinal vascular disease) Neovascular AMD Presence of small bowel or liver disease impairing oral tablet absorption

trial_design.concealment: Patients with diagnosed atrophic macular degeneration will be invited to participate at the Sydney Retina Clinic & Day Surgery, Australia. All patients will be treated with either saffron (20 mg/day, oral supplementation) or placebo for a period of 3 months, and then crossed over to the alternate treatment arm for a further 3 months. allocation not concealed.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a common cause of visual loss in older people, and currently treatment options for dry AMD are limited. This study will investigate whether saffron supplements are an effective treatment for dry AMD.
